case_name: Legal Representatives of V. D. Talwar v. J. K. Iron and Steel Company Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 673 of 1962 was filed by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 22, 1960, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 740 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDIICTION Civil Appeal No. 673 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 22, 1960, of the Patna High Court in Misc. judicial Case No. 740 of 1958.

facts.text: V. D. Talwar was employed as the General Manager of Messrs J. K. Iron and Steel Company Ltd., Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: V. D. Talwar, who was assessee before the taxing authorities and whose legal representatives on his death are appellants before us, was employed as the General Manager of Messrs J. K. Iron and Steel Company Ltd., Kanpur.

facts.text: Terms of employment incorporated in appointment letter dated February 7, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of his employment as agreed upon by the assessee and the Company were incorporated in an appointment letter dated February 7, 1946.

facts.text: Formal memorandum of agreement executed on February 9, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: A formal memorandum of agreement was also executed between the parties on February 9, 1946.

facts.text: Assessee joined service on May 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The assessce actually joined the service of the companypany on May 1, 1946.

facts.text: Pay fixed at Rs. 2,000 per month with increment of Rs. 100 p.a. subject to deductions.

anchor.surface_text: According to the service agreement the pay of the assessee was fixed at Rs. 2,000/per month with an increment of Rs. 100/- p.a. subject to certain deductions for income-tax, absence of duty etc.,

facts.text: Period of service was for five years.

anchor.surface_text: According to the agreement the period of service was for five years.

facts.text: Termination of service within five years on twelve months notice or salary in lieu.

anchor.surface_text: Clauses 5 and 6 of the appointment -letter read- Period of agreement of service to be five years. Termination of service if within five years to be on numberice of twelve months on either side or salary in lieu thereof.

facts.text: Services terminated with effect from August 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: We have stated earlier that the assessee joined his post as General Manager on May 1, 1946. The services of the assessee were however terminated with effect from August 31, 1947.

facts.text: Services terminated not for default or misconduct but because company did not want to continue employment. Admitted by parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is the admitted case of the parties that the services of the assessee were number terminated for any default or misconduct on the part of the assessee, but the services were terminated because the companypany did number want to companytinue the assessee in their employment.

facts.text: No twelve months notice given; instead paid Rs. 18,096/1/0 on September 12, 1947, being Rs. 25,200 minus income-tax Rs. 7,103/15/0.

anchor.surface_text: It is also the admitted case that numbernotice of twelve Months for the termination of the service was given by the companypany to the assessce as required by the companytract, In lieu of the numberice the companypany paid to the assessee on September 12, 1947 a sum of Rs. 18,096/1/0- which was the amount companyputed as salary for twelve months after deduction of incometax at the source.

facts.text: Assessee gave stamped receipt for Rs. 18,096/1/0 in full and final settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee gave a stamped receipt to the companypany for having recieved Rs. 18,096/1/0 in full and final settlement of all his claims and dues against the employer companypany.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 25,200 taxable as revenue receipt for 1948-49 assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In making the assessment for the year 1948-1949 the Income- tax Officer held that the sum of Rs. 25,200/- was a revenue receipt of the assessee liable to be taxed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: Assessee claimed it was compensation for loss of employment.

anchor.surface_text: and rejected the claim of the assessee that the said sum was companypensation for loss of employment and the tax amounting to Rs. 7,1031/15/0 should be refunded to him.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 25,200 not taxable as compensation for loss of service.

anchor.surface_text: rhe asscssee took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who held that the sum of Rs. 25,200/, though calculated on the basis of twelve times his monthly salary, was numberhing but companypensation for the loss of service and was therefore number taxable as income in the shape of salaries.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reversed AAC and held Rs. 25,200 taxable as salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: Then there was an appeal to the Incometax Appellate Tribunal which reversed the finding of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and held that the amount of Rs. 25,200/- paid to the assessee was really salary in lieu of twelve months numberice

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s.66(1): whether Rs.25,200 revenue income liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 66 1 of the Indian Income-Tax Act, the Incometax Appellate Tribunal referred the following question of law for the opinion of the High Court Whether the sum of Rs. 25,200/- received by the assessee during the Previous year was the revenue income of the assessee liable to tax under the Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Patna High Court answered question against assessee on November 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment and order dated November 22,1960 the High Court answered the question against the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave; present appeal brought.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then obtained special leave -from this companyrt in pursuance whereof the present appeal has been brought to this companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rs. 25,200 was salary in lieu of notice, taxable as revenue income, not capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we think that the High Court companyrectly answered the question.

facts.text: V. D. Talwar died; legal representatives are appellants.

anchor.surface_text: V. D. Talwar, who was assessee before the taxing authorities and whose legal representatives on his death are appellants before us,

facts.text: Judgment delivered by K. DAB J. on March 26, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 26. The judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAB J.-

holdings.text: Compensation for loss of office means a payment to holder of an office as compensation for being deprived of profits to which as between himself and his employer he would, but for an act of deprivation by his employer or some third party such as the Legislature, have been entitled.

anchor.surface_text: In Henry H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. Arthur Foster and Henry H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. Joseph Foster 1 , Romer, L. J. said Compensation for loss of office is a well-known term and it means a payment to holder of an office as companypensation for being deprived of profits to which as between himself and his employer he would, but for an act of deprivation by his employer or some third party such as the Legislature, have been entitled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts definition from Romer L.J. in Foster cases, accepted by this Court in Sheppard.

holdings.text: The two terms in cls. 5 and 6 of the appointment letter and cls. 1 and 21 of the memorandum of agreement must be read together and so read the true position that emerges is that the contract of service provided that V. D. Talwar could serve either for five years or, if the company so elected, for a shorter period upon the terms mentioned in cl. 21. If complied with, no surrender or deprivation of rights.

holdings.text: The present case comes under the first class of cases where the contract persists and the amount is payable under the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes from cases of total abandonment; follows Evershed's classification in Henley.

holdings.text: The principle which will apply in a case like this is that laid down in Dale v. de Soissons: payment per contract terms is not compensation for loss of office as no deprivation of rights.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the High Court has rightly pointed out that the principle which will apply in a case like this is that laid down in Dale H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. de Soissons 3 . There the respondent was employed as assistant to the managing director of a companypany

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Dale: employee got exactly what entitled under contract, no surrender of rights.

holdings.text: There being no deprivation of his rights under the contract, the payment cannot be said to be compensation for loss of office within the meaning of that expression.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore got exactly what he was entitled to Under the terms of his employment and he was number deprived of any rights Under the companytract of service. There being numberdeprivation of his rights under the companytract, the payment cannot be said to be companypensation for loss of office within the meaning of that expression.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No act of deprivation; payment exactly per contract terms.

holdings.text: What has been paid to the appellant is his salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: What has been paid to the appellant is his salary in lieu of numberice. If that is the true position then the amount paid is taxable under s. 7 of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment calculated as 12 months salary instead of notice, per contract.

holdings.text: The amount paid is taxable under s. 7 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. It is not compensation for loss of employment within the meaning of Explanation 2 thereto.

anchor.surface_text: the amount paid is taxable under s. 7 of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922. It is number companypensation for loss of employment within the meaning of Explanation 2 thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Salary in lieu taxable as income from salaries; does not qualify for exclusion as compensation.

precedents.citation: Henry H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. Arthur Foster and Henry H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. Joseph Foster 1

precedents.case_name: Henry v. Arthur Foster and Henry v. Joseph Foster
precedents.cited_proposition: Compensation for loss of office means a payment to holder of an office as compensation for being deprived of profits to which as between himself and his employer he would, but for an act of deprivation by his employer or some third party such as the Legislature, have been entitled.
precedents.cited_holding: Compensation for loss of office is a well-known term and it means a payment to holder of an office as compensation for being deprived of profits to which as between himself and his employer he would, but for an act of deprivation by his employer or some third party such as the Legislature, have been entitled.

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City 1, Bombay v. E. D. Sheppard, Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City 1, Bombay v. E. D. Sheppard, Bombay 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. E. D. Sheppard
precedents.cited_proposition: Accepted the same meaning of compensation for loss of office as stated by Romer L.J. in the Foster cases.

precedents.citation: Hunter M. Inspector of Taxes v. Dewhurst 1

anchor.surface_text: Hunter M. Inspector of Taxes v. Dewhurst 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment for giving up potential claims under an article by entering a new bargain is not income; distinguishes cases of deprivation from no deprivation.
precedents.cited_holding: Dewhurst was not paid in terms of article 109 but entered into a new bargain pursuant to which he was paid 10,000 in consideration of giving up his potential claims under article 109, which was not income.

precedents.citation: Henley v. Murry H. M. Inspector of Taxes 2

anchor.surface_text: Henley v. Murry H. M. Inspector of Taxes 2

precedents.cited_proposition: Two kinds of cases: one where contract persists and amount payable under contract; other where contract abandoned and sum paid for total abandonment of contractual rights.
precedents.cited_holding: What was paid was in consideration of surrendering right to serve and be remunerated to end of contractual engagement.

precedents.citation: Dale H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. de Soissons 3

anchor.surface_text: Dale H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. de Soissons 3

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment made strictly under the terms of service agreement for early termination is not compensation for loss of office but what the employee is entitled to under the contract.
precedents.cited_holding: The payment was not compensation for loss of office; respondent surrendered no rights and got exactly what entitled under contract.

precedents.citation: Duff M. Inspector of Taxes v. Barlow 1

anchor.surface_text: Duff M. Inspector of Taxes v. Barlow 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment as compensation for loss of right to future remuneration under earlier agreement upon premature termination is not remuneration but compensation for giving up a right.
precedents.cited_holding: The sum of 4,000 was received not under contract of employment or as remuneration but as compensation for giving up right to remuneration.
